Find all the constraints (i,k,x) where the bit j is set in x. For these constraints, we need to have at least one of a_i or a_k set to have the bit.

children.text:
We need to cover all the edges (i,j) in the constraints where the constraint's x has bit j. 

We can model this as a graph where each constraint (i,k,x) with bit j set forms an edge (i,k). Then the problem reduces to selecting a subset of nodes such that every edge has at least one endpoint selected. This is the vertex cover problem for each bit's graph.
children.label: high_level_plan

children.text:
The minimal vertex cover would allow us to set the bit in as few elements as possible, thus keeping others unset. But the vertex cover is NP-hard, so this can't be done for large n. 

Hmm, but perhaps there's a greedy approach here.
